qas.question: Where does uranium rank among elements in terms of its abundance in the Earth's crust?
Along with potassium-40 and uranium, the decay of what element is a primary heat source driving plate tectonics?
In what state is the Earth's outer core?
Where does uranium rank among elements in terms of its abundance in the Earth's atmosphere?
Along with potassium-40 and uranium, the decay of what element is a primary cooling source driving plate tectonics?
In what state is the Earth's inner core?
In what state is the Earth's middle core?

context: Uranium is a naturally occurring element that can be found in low levels within all rock, soil, and water. Uranium is the <a0_0><b4_0>51st<b4_0/><a0_0/> element in order of abundance in the Earth's crust. Uranium is also the highest-numbered element to be found naturally in significant quantities on Earth and is almost always found combined with other elements. Along with all elements having atomic weights higher than that of iron, it is only naturally formed <a1_0><b5_0>in supernovae<b5_0/><a1_0/>. The decay of uranium, <a2_0><b6_0>thorium<b6_0/><a2_0/>, and potassium-40 in the Earth's mantle is thought to be the main source of heat that keeps the outer core <a3_0><b7_0><b8_0>liquid<b8_0/><b7_0/><a3_0/> and drives mantle convection, which in turn drives plate tectonics.
